TCalc: Telescope-Calculator
  • Tcalc
  • Functions
  • age_eye
Edit this page

Functions¶

functions.Lmag_limit(D_o)¶

Calculates the magnitude of the faintest star which can be seen from the telescope

Parameters

D_o (float) – Diameter of Objective/Aperture (mm)

Returns

Limiting Magnitude (LM) of telescope

Return type

float

functions.Max_eyepiece(f_R, D_eye=7, age=None)¶

Calulates the maximum focal length of eyepiece you can use on the telescope :param D_eye: Diameter of Eyepiece (mm); default is 7 mm :type D_eye: float :param f_R: Focal Ratio/f-number of telescope :type f_R: float

Returns

The maximum focal length of eyepiece (:math: f_{e-max}) you can use with your telescope

Return type

float

functions.Max_magnification(D_o)¶

Calulates the maximum usable magnification of the telescope :param D_o: Diameter of Objective/Aperture (mm) :type D_o: float

Returns

Maximum Usable Magnification (:math: M_max) of the telescope

Return type

float

Note

The maximum usable magnification also depends upon seeing.

functions.Min_eyepiece(f_o, M_max)¶

Calulates the minimum focal length of eyepiece you can use on the telescope :param f_o: Focal length of Objective/Aperture (mm) :type f_o: float :param M_max: Maximum usable magnification :type M_max: float

Returns

The minimum focal length of eyepiece (:math: f_{e-min}) you can use with your telescope

Return type

float

functions.Min_magnification(D_o, D_eye=7, age=None)¶

Calulates the minimum usable magnification of the telescope :param D_o: Diameter of Objective/Aperture (mm) :type D_o: float :param D_eye: Diameter of Eyepiece (mm); default is 7 mm :type D_eye: float

Returns

Minimum Usable Magnification (:math: M_min) of the telescope

Return type

float

functions.dawes_lim(D_o)¶

Calulates the Reosultion of the telescope according to the Dawes Limit

Parameters

D_o (float) – Diameter of Objective/Aperture (mm)

Returns

Resolving power of the telescope arroding to Dawes Limit (arc-sec)

Return type

float

Note

This function is generally useful when you are doing filter-less observations. For operation with filters, check Resolution Power function.

functions.exit_pupil(f_e, f_R)¶

Calulates the Exit Pupil of the telescope & eyepiece pair :param f_e: Focal Length of eyepiece (mm) :type f_e: float :param f_R: Focal Ratio of telescope :type f_R: float

Returns

Diameter of Exit Pupil(:math: D_EP) (mm)

Return type

float

Note

For optimal usage, :math: D_EP pprox 2-3 mm is the optimum range for maximizing the resolving power of the eye

functions.focal_ratio(f_o, D_o)¶

Calculates the Focal Ratio for the telescope :param f_o: Focal Length of Objective/Aperture (mm) :type f_o: float :param D_o: Diameter of Objective/Aperture (mm) :type D_o: float

Returns

Focal Ratio/f-number (:math: f_R) of the telescope

Return type

float

functions.magnification(f_o, f_e)¶

Calculates the Angular Magnification for the telescope :param f_o: Focal Length of Objective/Aperture (mm) :type f_o: float :param f_e: Focal Length of Eyepiece (mm) :type f_e: float

Returns

Visual Magnification (M) of the telescope

Return type

float

functions.resolving_power(W, D_o)¶

Calulates the Reosultion of the telescope

Parameters

  • W (float) – Wavelength of light recieved (nm)

  • D_o (float) – Diameter of Objective/Aperture (mm)

Returns

Resolving power of the telescope (:math: P_R) (arc-sec)

Return type

float

Note

This function is generally useful when you are using filters. For filter-less observations, check Dawes Limit function.

functions.surface_brightness(D_EP)¶

Calculates the surface brightness of the object as seen from the telescope

Parameters

D_o (float) – Diameter of Exit Pupil (mm)

Returns

Surface Brightness (SB)

Return type

percentage

functions.true_fov(M, fov_e=50)¶

Calulates the True Field of View (FOV) of the telescope & eyepiece pair :param fov_e: FOV of eyepiece; default 50 deg :type fov_e: float :param M: Magnification of Telescope :type M: float

Returns

True Field of View (deg)

Return type

float
